messageBody:
Kent Beck wrote:

> I can see what you mean about the licensing encouraging big clunky classes.
> The challenge for all tool vendors is to find a business model to replace
> perpetual per-seat licenses. That was the model that built some big software
> tool companies (Rational, etc.), but it isn't working well any more. I don't
> have the answer--it depends on what people and companies are willing to pay
> for--but there needs to be some way to return a profit from investment in
> software tools. Per-class licensing is intended to make quick, small-scale
> use of tools inexpensive, but it doesn't seem to scale well. Over the long
> run I think service models based on proprietary software (a la
> Salesforce.com) will become more common, but it's hard to see how to apply
> that to software tools at the moment.

I think I understand the antiquated licence scheme it's meant to
replace, but I would rather pay a tiered subscription fee based on a
measure of how much I use the software (say, the number of outcomes it
detects?), rather than what the resulting design looks like.

> Anyway, objection noted. Thanks.

You're welcome, and thank you for noting it. I know it's a knotty
problem to solve. I can't claim to know better, but I know what I don't
like, and I don't like this (quite). Of course, I'm not exactly in
Agitar's market for this product right now, so my opinion is largely
theoretical in nature at present.

Take care.
